Situation1: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I stared at my phone, rereading Mia’s message: “Can we do something special this weekend? I’ll miss you so much.” It was our last weekend together before she moved abroad, and I knew how much it meant to her. She wanted every moment to count, and honestly, so did I. But then my volunteer coordinator’s reminder popped up: “Don’t forget your shift starts at 9 a.m. sharp on Saturday!” I’d promised to help at the shelter, and I knew they counted on me to be reliable. Still, I also knew a couple of others could cover the early hours if I was late. My heart twisted as I imagined Mia’s disappointed face if I cut our time short, but I also pictured the coordinator’s frown if I didn’t show up on time. Both sides expected something from me, and I felt pulled in two directions, guilt and anxiety swirling inside me as I tried to figure out what to do.
